entry.title: The Pucci extremal operators
entry.content:
Let $\Omega\subset \mathbb{R^n}$ be an open subset with smooth boundary. We consider the following second-order elliptic equation in the nondivergence form

\begin{equation}\label{eq:main-1} \sum_{i,j=1}^n a_{ij}(x)\partial_{ij}v(x) = 0 \qquad\text{in}\;\Omega \tag{1} \end{equation}

under the uniform ellipticity assumption

\begin{equation}\label{eq:main-2} \lambda \mathbb{I} \preceq \big( a_{ij}(x) \big)_{ij} \preceq \Lambda \mathbb{I} \qquad\text{for all}\;x\in \Omega \tag{2} \end{equation}

Here I\mathbb{I}I is the identity n×nn\times nn×n matrix. We write A(x)=(aij(x))ij\mathbb{A}(x) = \big( a_{ij}(x)\big)_{ij}A(x)=(aij​(x))ij​ for simplicity.

The main classical result on equation \eqref{eq:main-1} is the DeGiorgi-Nash-Moser’s Holder estimate. No other assumption on (aij(x))\big(a_{ij}(x)\big)(aij​(x)) is needed, so they can be discontinuous. To formulate \eqref{eq:main-1} in the viscosity solution framework if (aij(x))\big(a_{ij}(x)\big)(aij​(x)) is discontinuous, we use the Pucci extremal operators.

Then λI⪯A⪯ΛI⟺λ∣ξ∣2≤∑i,j=1nAijξiξj≤Λ∣ξ∣2⟺eigenvalues of  A  belongs to  [λ,Λ]. \begin{aligned} \lambda \mathbb{I} \preceq A \preceq \Lambda \mathbb{I} &\qquad \Longleftrightarrow\qquad \lambda |\xi|^2 \leq \sum_{i,j=1}^n A_{ij}\xi_i\xi_j \leq \Lambda |\xi|^2 \\ &\qquad \Longleftrightarrow\qquad \text{eigenvalues of}\;A\;\text{belongs to}\;[\lambda,\Lambda]. \end{aligned} λI⪯A⪯ΛI​⟺λ∣ξ∣2≤i,j=1∑n​Aij​ξi​ξj​≤Λ∣ξ∣2⟺eigenvalues ofAbelongs to[λ,Λ].​ Let Aλ,Λ\mathcal{A}_{\lambda, \Lambda}Aλ,Λ​ denote the class of such matrices.

Definition (Pucci operators). For an n×nn\times nn×n matrix MMM, we define P+(M)=sup⁡A∈Aλ,Λ{∑i,j=1nAijMij},P−(M)=inf⁡A∈Aλ,Λ{∑i,j=1nAijMij}. \begin{aligned} \mathcal{P}^+(M) = \sup_{A\in \mathcal{A}_{\lambda,\Lambda}} \left\lbrace \sum_{i,j=1}^n A_{ij}M_{ij} \right\rbrace, \qquad \mathcal{P}^-(M) = \inf_{A\in \mathcal{A}_{\lambda,\Lambda}} \left\lbrace \sum_{i,j=1}^n A_{ij}M_{ij} \right\rbrace. \end{aligned} P+(M)=A∈Aλ,Λ​sup​{i,j=1∑n​Aij​Mij​},P−(M)=A∈Aλ,Λ​inf​{i,j=1∑n​Aij​Mij​}.​

Let v∈C(Ω)v\in \mathrm{C}(\Omega)v∈C(Ω), the following two conditions are equivalent in the viscosity sense:

entry.content:
The basic properties of solution to a Laplace equation Δu=0\Delta u = 0Δu=0, i.e., a harmonic function can be summarized as follows.

  • Mean value properties and direct consequences
    • The mean value property
    • Consequences
      • Strong max/min principles (from mean-value)
      • Harnack inequality (from mean-value)
      • Interior derivative estimates (from mean-value)
  • Green’s function and representations
    • The fundamental solution
    • Poisson integral formula in the whole space
    • Green’s function
    • Consequences
      • Strong max/min principle (from integral representation)
      • Harnack inequality (from integral representation)
      • Interior derivative estimates (from integral representation)
  • The Perron’s method of subharmonic functions

Mean value properties and direct consequences

The mean value property

Let Ω\OmegaΩ be a domain in Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn and u∈C2(Ω)u\in \mathrm{C}^2(\Omega)u∈C2(Ω) be a function.
